Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
@BATTLE
No, no, no. Faster on that coal.
I know what I'm doing.

Fields.MenuText: Get some shuteye. You're going to need it.
You let me worry about the Belle.
If you're worried about Aurora, she's a kitten compared to me.

Fields.DialogueText: I'd be more than happy to, Capitán.
Si, Capitán. Lo siento, Capitán.
And you, Kanzaki. Keep your eye on your own work. You can pick up where Zamora's left off, for starters. You seem to have it figured out.
That grate looks exactly the way it did a minute ago.
Claro que si, genio. It's a floor full of coal.
Stop joking around, all right? You know what this Kami is like.
That's for me to know and you two to hopefully never find out.
What, she can sense how many rocks she's burning?
Gah! Capitán!
Kanchou.
Zamora, is it? Congratulations. You're on middle watch. The usual guy's under the weather.
Si, Capitán.
Si, Capitán!
Hai, Kanchou.
You didn't tell them why you were the one to deliver the news.
Should I have?
I would have imagined it to be a subordinate's responsibility. Mine, for instance.
Being able to teleport certainly has its advantages. I figured you had more important things to worry about.
Besides, there are a lot of foreigners on the crew. I'm trying to get to know everyone a little better.
Ty vresh'.
I'm not lying.
By omission.
All right, case in point. I delivered the news myself for their sake. You can be a little... intense.
You will learn my virtues, Kapitan, or you will be buried by them.
I'm glad she's on our side...
I figured you did.
Stay out of my business, why don't you?
Your business? You're the one who won't shut up on watch!
So what if I talk to myself? My eyes are right where they ought to be!
Try telling the Kami that!
Da, try telling me that.
Gah! A-Aurora-sama!
Opposite watches, effective immediately. Opposite mealtimes, as well. I will not have your bickering fouling up the air aboard me.
Hai, Kami-sama.
Sí, Aloja.
Pathetic.

Fields.MenuText: Couldn't have said it better myself.
Can't they just get along?
Don't scare them, Aurora.

Fields.DialogueText: You will learn.
That is little of our concern.
Vzdor. I'm not even trying.
I'll say this, Aurora... some of what I overheard revolved around you.
Did it, Kapitan? Or did it revolve around what they have heard of me?
You're not exactly dispelling the rumors.
I hope never to. You wouldn't find it useful for your reputation to precede you?
Not if it inspired fear.
Fear is unavoidable. Our advantage over the Morganas is that there is more than one type.
What's that supposed to mean?
*ALARM*
Only that it takes terror to defeat terror. Just ask Calamity.
@BATTLE
Room for one more.
Of course, Aurora. Sit--
@BATTLE
That wasn't a question.
Of course not.
What have you heard about me, Kapitan?

Fields.MenuText: A lot of things. I'm not sure what I believe.
Some pretty chilling things, if we're being honest.
No more than what the dossier said.

Fields.DialogueText: Then you alone may learn from me.
Call them as you see them, Kapitan. Lie to yourself and you lie to me.
Straight to the point, at least. Khorosho.
Well, the first thing I heard about you was that you're the only thing standing between Leningrad and oblivion.
Do you believe it?
Well, that second thing is provably nonsense. But I don't think it matters what I believe. You're a powerhouse, and we need powerhouses to win this war.
So far.
Hmm.
Well? Do I pass?
You've been spared the lecture on democratic centralism, at least.
Shame. I imagine it's riveting.
Those two new shirkers I keep having to break up could tell you all about it.
Zamora and Kanzaki? They're not all bad. As long as they're not in each other's presence, I think they get along all right.
One fears me. The other disrespects me. They're too busy tripping over their own starstruck feet to parlay this into unity.
Well, give them time. There's a learning curve to all this, even for Belles.
On this we agree. But time given can also be taken.
On that note... I've also heard that your original crew has the only human-on-Morgana kill.
... They come. Let us carve out some time for ourselves.
*ALARM*
The second was that you personally execute crew who fall behind.
I draw no such distinctions. You know the Morganas for their ability to appear wherever they please.
Hmm. Aurora, you don't call them "Rusalki?"
Steady on. We're entering a hot zone.
Humans are capable of vigilance against the Morganas, Kapitan. We must simply find the right ones.
Let's not make the crew paranoid.
I am aware of that habit among my younger sisters. To speak of fairytale beasts is a poor example for a First Comrade to set.

Fields.MenuText: Nothing we can do about it. It's just how people make sense of the situation.
You don't see the appeal of slaying the monsters you grew up hearing stories of?
Why don't you put a stop to it? I'm sure they listen to you.

Fields.DialogueText: Shackles are familiar to the lifelong prisoner.
Idealist garbage.
The glass has been shattered already. There is little point in refilling it.
I'm taking over the radio, Kapitan.
Got an announcement?
An ultimatum.
Sailors! The old order is no more. Our enemy has torn down the veil between your world and theirs.
... I see.
Do not cling to the faceless comforts of flame and metal. Sin. Fire. Disease. Malice. Recognize the faces our foes have given to the age-old enemies of mankind. Memorize them. Hate them.
Captain, we've established contact with the enemy!
*BOOM*
Those among you who fought alongside me that first day in Leningrad: Serve as an example to your comrades. Tell them what it was to tear Calamity limb from limb.
*BOOM*
What walks may be crippled. What speaks may be silenced. What glares may be blinded. They know this. They use this. They fear this.
So do you all. Conquer your fear, for your unity is the sum of theirs.
As for myself: I am Aurora, and the darkness cannot undo the dawn.
*BOOM*
Aurora, they're on top of us!
Lozh'. Listen to the radio.
The crew... they're cheering?
It is we who are on top of them.
@BATTLE
Kapitan.
What was that earlier? Your... ultimatum?
Aurora?
The truth.

Fields.MenuText: It was certainly one hell of a speech.
According to whom?
You're not making sense.

Fields.DialogueText: There will be others, until the day they are not needed.
Me, at first. Your crew, with time.
Perhaps I chose you to teach you my way of thinking.
There is a difference between fact and truth, Kapitan. Facts cannot be changed. Truth can.
I'm not sure I follow. If everyone has the facts, how do they not all know the same truth?
Do you think that the Morganas do not know we can kill them?
Well, they certainly don't stay dead.
The Romanovs once ruled my country by divine decree. To defy them was to spit in the face of God Himself.
But even parched peasants can find it in them to spit.
You're talking in riddles.
You are not a Belle, Kapitan. But you do not need to be one to understand that we live in yesterday's impossibilities.
The Morganas do not stay dead. We kill them even so, because we must do so or perish.
And if they just keep coming?
The workers rose to meet each new day even before they seized their own destiny. When the moment came, those who would not were cast aside.
Well, it really seems to resonate with the crew. But you might spook the new blood with that kind of talk.
They know who I am. They will know who they are soon enough... and so will we.
*ALARM*
Take tea with me after this battle, Kapitan. We have much yet to learn about each other.
Let's survive until then.
@BATTLE
A-Aurora-sama?

Fields.MenuText: He's just trying to be polite.

Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
@BATTLE
Speak, Comrade Kanzaki.
I... realize we may have gotten off on the wrong--
Stop.
Hai--
Your quarrel is not with me. What do you have against the Ispanets?
Ispanets... Oh, you mean Zamora? It's... it's his work ethic, Aurora-sama. He's slapdash and peevish and...
It is a distraction.
Hai.
That is your problem. How are you to achieve your potential if you remain focused on his? Focus on yourself and leave him to me.
Hai, Aurora-sa--
And enough with the honorifics, Comrade Kanzaki. Call me Comrade Aurora.
... Comrade Aurora.
Better. Vernut'sya k rabote.

Fields.MenuText: What was that all about?
Maybe now he'll leave you alone.

Fields.DialogueText: Finger-pointing and snooping. It is beneath your concern.
That is indeed the goal of the Revolution, broadly speaking.
There is a difference between respect and groveling.
I tire of people reporting on each other's mistakes to me, Kapitan.
In fairness, it's not unheard of in your... circles.
Dissent is poison. All well and good. But I am not some brickbat to be wielded in petty squabbles.
Even so... what do you do with someone who isn't living up to your standards?
I find another standard for them. There is a place for everyone, after all.
Remarkably merciful.
Practical.
Lousy, jumped-up ghost of a murderous--
Sailor.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Capitán!
Good hustle on these decks. They're sparkling.
Gracias, Capitán.
Listen, while we're alone. What's your deal with Aurora?
Capitán, I don't want to bother you with it.
I can order you to bother me if you prefer.
Are you a religious person, Capitán?
We're not talking about me here.
We've got people from all over on this crew, Capitán. I don't agree with all of them.
My brothers fought for Yagüe in Morocco and Spain. I won't pretend we were angels, but God was on our side.
But... just look at her.
Aurora?
A godless warrior for a godless regime - one of the strongest of the Alojas, no less. When the Brujas are gone, what war will she fight?

Fields.MenuText: That's none of your concern.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe not. But I'm not the only one whose mind that's crossed.

Fields.MenuText: The Belles are here to protect us.
Then why are you here?

Fields.DialogueText: They can't even protect themselves without us. You might as well look to your sidearm to save you.
Orders are orders.
I just can't shake the feeling, Capitán. We used to believe that ships didn't come to life. Now we're certain that they don't turn against us. Nothing... nothing stays the same, Capitán.
Heh. Case in point.
Your concerns have been noted. Get to your station and leave this to me.
It is the air, Kapitan, keeping me from walking the decks. I'm reminded of Tsushima.
Like the weather?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
You're here early.
Perhaps I phrased it incorrectly. The new crew I am surrounded by...

Fields.MenuText: They've gotten us this far.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed. Even so...
Have you ever watched something terrible happen and been powerless to stop it?

Fields.MenuText: They're getting used to you.
They're a handful, I admit.

Fields.DialogueText: As expected. They would not be here for long if they did not. And yet...
Not to mention petty. But, Kapitan...
I feel a war story coming.
Thirty-five years ago, the Baltic Fleet sailed halfway around the world only to be obliterated in a single day.
Admiral Tōgō was waiting for us. Everyone who could have been a match for him had been removed or killed.
Even asleep, I knew the horror that surrounded me. Steel bursting into flames. Ships thrice my size exploding. Five thousand souls wasted, at least.
We're not going to let that happen.
I have no doubt of your intentions, Kapitan. But I sensed once that I was in the presence of those unequal to our task. Such a one may walk among us now.
You shouldn't be so hard on the crew. You've trained them well.
Nyet, Kapitan. You have talked to one who would sooner see me slip beneath the waves than stand victorious at my side.
Zamora? How did you--
I didn't know. Now I do. And now I know you share my suspicion.
I will be keeping an eye on that one, Kapitan. And not just because fascists sent him.
Heh. You know, they put me in the 5th Column before Tsushima. The irony positively boggles the mind.
Nothing slips by you, Aurora.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Ah! Kanchou, my apologies. A quick prayer before we set out again.
Now, what if you're wrong about there being a traitor aboard?

Fields.MenuText: Nosiness can come in handy.

Fields.DialogueText: There will always be people who excel at finding others' flaws.

Fields.MenuText: I don't like spying on my crew on a hunch.
Better than being buried.

Fields.DialogueText: Call it an instinct, then.
Wise words.
At ease, Kanzaki. Listen, you respect the Belle. I wanted to ask a favor of you.
Anything.
Keep an eye out for anything suspicious, all right? She's under the impression that we've got an infiltrator.
Some Funayūrei plot?
Maybe, maybe not. But consider yourself my inside man while I'm otherwise occupied above.
Hai, Kanchou. But why me?
Because quite frankly, you've got a critical eye for the goings-on around you. I'm not going to call you a busybody, but it should come in handy.
I've been at sea since I could swim, Kanchou. I can't help it.
Good. Don't. Keep me posted.
Hai!
Well, well, well. Someone's learning my virtues.
Then we will apologize to our deputy for wasting his time. I would prefer to admit error than to be blindsided.
Well, that'll be inconvenient. The papers say you don't make mistakes.
Ochen' khorosho. Then I will not. I trust this will be the last misgiving you express on the subject.
Her words, not mine...
*KNOCK*
Come in.
Kanchou.
Kanzaki. Find anything out?
Not specifically. I wanted to ask you a question, actually.
Please.
Aurora-sa... Comrade Aurora. What do you think of her?
Nagasaki. I started in the Navy not long after my father was killed... after this whole madness started.
Where did you say you were from?
I try, Kanchou. I have since I left home. I hope she knows that.

Fields.MenuText: I watch my step around her. You should too.
Irrelevant. I'm her captain, and that's how we're fighting this war.
I have nothing but faith in her, Kanzaki. You heard her speech.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose... If I'm stuck on the other side of the world, it's best to be around someone formidable.
At least some of the stories are true, then. It definitely beats what I was hearing back home.
That's a good word for it. I think everyone's lost someone or something to the Morganas, or knows someone who has. Well, we're glad to have you. You're safe here.
I'd like to think so. She's...
Hmm?
She really stirs the imagination, you know? Like... I don't know. A mountain. Something you can't help but feel small next to.
*ALARM*
Heh. You're not the first. Let me know if anything goes on.
Hai, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
Ah, brilliant! I've been waiting for this one.
That may be the first time I've seen you smile.
Communiqué from Command, Aurora. It's for you.
I make no secret of my passions. You'll find I rather enjoy the INPF lend-lease initiative. There's nothing like international cooperation.

Fields.MenuText: All right, now I know you're up to something.
It's the only way we're going to win this war.
I'm surprised it's even gotten off the ground.

Fields.DialogueText: Congratulations, Kapitan. Not many see what goes on behind the scenes at Leningrad.
Autarky has its time and place, and now is not it.
Desperation is a powerful thing.
Hmm... Oh, dear me. Surely you can do better than that, London.
Are they really letting you in on the negotiations? I wasn't aware Belles had any input.
Ordinarily, we do not. There is a wonderful story behind that, if I might bend your ear.
Bend away.
There was a British envoy who made his way aboard me in the early days of the war. He made some smart remark about that business in the Dogger Bank in '04.
The friendly fire incident? Russian warships versus British fishermen?
A skittish kapitan's paranoia. Vigilance has a price. I should know. I was there.
I told him as much, and I opined that we are fortunate to finally live in a world where ships may open their eyes.
All the better to see exactly who and where we're firing at.
I assume he got the message.
As did one of our admirals. They send their correspondence my way when they need some extra... urgency.
So that's what that international incident in the Times was all about.
It barely merited the term. But the newspapers know as well as I that what you say is less important than the way you say it.
*ALARM*
I'll still take you over anything the Morganas say.
Be thankful they haven't mastered subtext.
@BATTLE
Now, then... Tsk. Your Majesty, I know you can spare a few tens of thousands more boots than that...
Ey up, Kanzaki.
You're looking better. Back on watch so soon?
Now that I've got my sea legs, sure. My sea stomach and my sea head, too.
Ha! What are you doing out here? You should be home rubbing your wife's feet!
Ain't my wife yet.
Whose is she, then?
Ask your sisters. Twins, aren't they? They'll keep him busy.
Ha! Stay out of trouble.

Fields.MenuText: A little crude.
Looks like Kanzaki's made friends as well as enemies.
He certainly recovered quickly.

Fields.DialogueText: I've been around long enough to hear worse.
Don't judge a man by his enemies. Not exclusively.
Marvelous, is it not? We take care of our own, but you can't win a war from a sickbed.
I'm surprised they can be so casual out here...
You're trailing off.
... and aboard you, no less. Especially a Brit. Happy?
The Communists disdain to conceal their views and aims, Kapitan.
Very funny.
What is more productive, Comrade Kapitan: catching such refuse as floats down the Neva, or marching upstream to burn the factory that produces it?
I think I get it. You know that the crew aren't their countries, and you treat them as such.
This is the case until proven otherwise. Krasnoflotets Macnair wasn't even born when the Royal Navy crossed me in the Dogger Bank. We have more in common than you realize.
... You're a cruiser.
I am what my country has made me, and that country is what its people have made it. And if I can awaken to a higher calling, so can Comrade Macnair.
And the burning factory in this metaphor?
A ruling class with material incentive to remain asleep among the flames. Need I continue?
Whatever you burn, do those Morganas first.
Take heed, Kapitan. Whoever is caught napping after this war is lost to us.
@BATTLE
... And so it was that a single battle cost the old Empire nearly the full measure of its naval strength.
She's got a war story for every occasion. Someone with a smart mouth occasioned this one.
What did it cost me? Three months detained in Manila, at the mercy of the upstart American empire.
What's she talking about?
So I gathered. Just like any other old-timer, then.
She can hear you, you know.
Wha--
Am I boring you, Comrade Krasnoflotets?
N-no, ma'am!
Your watch is hereby doubled. An active mind must be properly exercised.
Yes, ma'am.
That's Comrade--
*BOOM*
To your stations at once! They will not make good on their surprise!
@BATTLE
How bad is it?
We defeated the ambush, Kapitan, but at little cost.

Fields.MenuText: "Little cost?" We lost Macnair.
How was this allowed to happen?
Are you all right?

Fields.DialogueText: One of roughly six hundred crew. He will be missed and then he will be replaced.
The Morganas slipped my senses. It will not happen a second time.
I'm here talking to you, aren't I? Don't concern yourself with me.
I'm glad we're still alive out here, but the Navy's going to have questions.
Doubtless. They will have answers. Macnair's family, as well.
I'll be taking care of that. You don't need to--
Lozh'. He was destroyed on my watch. I will take responsibility for the aftermath.
That's noble, Aurora.
It is merely right. Now, let me direct the cleanup. You're needed on the bridge.
It's just not fair.
What isn't fair?
Macnair. If I had still been on watch--
You weren't. Whose fault is that?
... Kanzaki, you don't mean--
You didn't make the schedule. I'm not assigning blame. But it's certainly not yours.
... No. No, it's not.
How's it looking out there today?
Clear but for a few stragglers. The Gulf of Finland is safe in our hands.

Fields.MenuText: Trust, but verify.
I still don't understand how they could have gotten one by you.
Some of the crew are having trouble believing it.

Fields.DialogueText: Wise words, and older than either of us.
Let me worry about that.
There will be such times over the course of this war.
Any news from Comrade Kanzaki?
What? No. None.
Perhaps we have been wasting his time. I am not too proud to admit this.
You don't think your senses were... sabotaged somehow, do you?
Nevozmozhno. We Belles are above you, Kapitan. Beyond you... and yet not.
So... they could be sabotaged?
If one of you truly wanted to destroy me, it would not be so difficult. A sufficiently powerful bomb snuck into my magazine would be enough to tear me apart from inside.
You take that idea remarkably well.
What I'm saying is to leave the Belle problems to the Belle.
I'm your captain, Aurora. That makes your problems my problems.
I am the First Comrade, Kapitan. Powerful I may be, but I am one among many.
But if the Morganas get the drop on us again--
Take your own advice, Kapitan. Keep your eyes on your own work.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Comrade Kapitan! What brings you to my quarters?
New Pravda with the last mail ship. Are you seeing this?
Aurora, we can't cover up what happened.
The enemy fell upon us in perfidious fashion and a watchman made a noble sacrifice to defeat them. It does not have to wound our collective pride.
Pride? We lost a man because you--
You did not step fully formed from the pages of your history, Kapitan. You were built from nothing by the people and the forces that shaped your existence.
Now, take all those people and things that created you, blend them together, and imagine springing into existence yesterday from a blueprint of that design.
I can't really do that.
Aurora? Aurora!
Hmm... Aurora taken unawares at the mouth of the Gulf of Finland... repels surprise attack by Rusalki... "Rusalki." Hmph. Is this Pravda or Bednota?
Look at the subheader. Macnair's mentioned.
Ah, yes. The heroic Englishman who drew the Morganas' fire.
Prove that it is not.

Fields.MenuText: Is that really what happened?
That's not how I remember it.
Who on earth told them that?

Fields.DialogueText: What good fortune that you do not talk to the papers.
I did, Kapitan. It is what is best for all of us in the long run.
Because I what, Kapitan? Because I wavered in defense of the revolution I embody? Because my grip upon its reins was relaxed by the deathless march of time?
Nyet, you cannot. Ask yourself which an honest Leningrad worker would rather believe: that their protector rusts at her watch, or that a noble cause unites the world and its people alongside her?
Set all that aside for now. We're not talking to the papers. We're talking person to person. Why did the Morganas catch you with your back turned?
Person to person?
This doesn't leave these quarters.
... I cannot say.
You don't know, or you can't tell me? Aurora--
*ALARM*
I think we could all use some reassurance. You can throw the first punch at the next Morgana I capture.
Aurora--
I'll even hold her arms for you. We're needed on the bridge, Comrade Kapitan.
@BATTLE
Sailors! If you weep for your fallen comrade, let it be to drown your enemy!
If they should strike you down, let a victory bloom from your sacrifice!
*BOOM*
But grieve another time and die another day. The Morganas must once more know your anger. May the sacrifice I deliver you fuel its flames for all the Baltic to see!
At ease, XO.
Sorry, Captain. The way she speaks... I won't let it go to my head.
That makes two of us.
@BATTLE
I assure you, Kapitan, I've broken any power she may have had.

Fields.MenuText: I don't want to get near one of those things.
Some days...
Beating her while she's down? It's barbaric.

Fields.DialogueText: Our guest today is Despair. Tempted to join the crew in their exercise, Kapitan?
*WHACK*
*SLAM*
*WHUD*
*CRACK*
With your world under attack, who would not be? But you carry yourself with dignity. It is commendable.
The way you pulled her off of her ship... I thought Belles and Morganas couldn't leave their hulls.
Kapitan, what is "down" to an enemy like this? She's physically superhuman. We can't contain her. What would you have us do in her crucial moment of vulnerability?
We're not supposed to.
... No further questions.
*RUMBLE*
She's sinking more quickly than I'd anticipated. Zamora there is an enthusiastic hand with a shovel, no matter what Kanzaki says.
Aren't you afraid of the Morganas doing that to you?
Nyet, Kapitan. If I fail, I know you will find a better use for me.
Aurora--
As should we all.
Let's take her down!
Enjoy it less.
I wonder if you and I expect different things from humanity.
Kanzaki, calm down. What's going on? Who is--
Zamora! He means to spread lies about Macnair's sacrifice!
Kanchou! I've found the interloper!

Fields.MenuText: Slow down. What's he saying? To whom?
Kanzaki, you were there. You saw what happened.
That's certainly not the worst thing he could be doing.

Fields.DialogueText: He was writing across from me in the mess this morning. We're lucky I can read upside down!
He fought the fires himself to the point of collapse! And that scoundrel means to say it didn't happen!
And don't I know it! ... Er, hai, Kanchou.
It's not necessarily a critical security issue, but it'll turn heads in Leningrad for sure.
Of course, Kanchou. Comrade Aurora should be aware now as well.
In any event, I'm glad you came to me about this.
You've told her already?
She wasn't in her quarters, but I thought she ought to know, so I--
*RUMBLE*
... Did you feel that? I knew she'd be cross, but--
*ALARM*
We've all got more important things to worry about right at this moment. Do me a favor?
Kanchou?
Next time, just break it to her personally.
@BATTLE
There are many things you need to know, Kapitan, and many you do not. Still more that would cleave your sanity from its moorings.
How can I know that?
Tell me you didn't hurt him.
Reactionary he may be, but he is still your crewman. I leave that decision to you.

Fields.MenuText: He has to stand trial.

Fields.DialogueText: For sedition - and stupidity besides. The military censor would have seen this coming from Skagerrak.

Fields.MenuText: Not everything can be solved with violence.
Politics, hell. He's not the only crewman on this ship from a fascist country.

Fields.DialogueText: Obviously. Do I look like a Narodnik to you?
Weeds in the garden.
Look, Aurora, if what Kanzaki says is true, I'll vouch for the work he's done. He's not a criminal.
Is it not a crime to undermine the unity of our crew? Of the country they serve?
They're united around a man who was obliterated by a lucky Morgana shell because you were looking the other way!
There's more than one story out there, Aurora. People talk. People whisper. And some of them say that you're showing your age.
I don't know what I believe. I don't think it matters what I believe. But I need to know why the Morganas are slipping by you of all Belles. You, who stakes your reputation on being invincible.
But you may rest assured that however I prosecute this war, it has nothing to do with any innate deficiency of mine.
Fully conscious of his crimes and awaiting your judgment in the brig.
How's Zamora?
The alarm will go off in ten seconds, Kapitan. I will meet you on the bridge to solve our immediate problem. Perhaps later we may talk about the things I have come to know.
Aurora... wait, what does that--
*ALARM*
Looks like the rust hasn't quite reached her head.
@BATTLE
I was given permission to take over Zamora's station in addition to mine. Our animosity aside... it is nice to not be stepping on someone's toes all the time.

Fields.MenuText: Stay out of trouble down here.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps. In any event, I suppose Zamora is too argumentative to be a saboteur in the first place. You have to be willing to put away your pride.
Kanzaki.
Hai, Kanchou!
At ease. I've got to say, this boiler has never looked cleaner. For a given value of clean, that is.
Don't worry, Kanchou. I'm my own worst critic!

Fields.MenuText: You're sure you can do the work of two?
It's good to have you aboard, Kanzaki.

Fields.DialogueText: Aurora was pleased to offer me the opportunity. She said I was a regular Stakhanov in the making, whatever that means.
I'm glad to be here. Thank you for believing in me.
Maybe I'll tease Aurora a little about this. You know, she was suspicious of your enthusiasm. Like you were trying too hard, I suppose.
Ha! Surely she knows there's no zealot like the convert?
Well, with any luck, we'll get Zamora back into a job. I appreciate your diligence, though it really isn't so terrible in the grand scheme of things.
Kanchou?
Sorry. Something you said just--
*ALARM*
Well, I'll leave you to it. This coal doesn't shovel itself!
It, uh... it sure doesn't.
@BATTLE
Will you stop calling him that? He has a name.
I trust you've come to a conclusion about our reactionary.
Materialist habit. I trust you'll come to understand.

Fields.MenuText: You talk a lot about trust for someone so cagey.
Very funny.
Would it kill you to be an idealist now and again?

Fields.DialogueText: The minute operational security hinges on you knowing how my mind works, you will know.
I thought you deserved at least a laugh out of the whole business.
Don't try to out-theory me, Kapitan. You will come up wanting.
Stinging though the defeat was, I learned much from Tsushima.
Another one of your stories, Aurora?
They tend to accumulate when you've been around as long as I have. Seen what I've seen. Done what I've done.
"Defeat is a common fate of a soldier. There is nothing to be ashamed of in it. The great point is whether we have performed our duty."
Tsushima... That was Admiral Tōgō, right?
To Admiral Rozhestvensky. In our own way, we have all done our duty thus far... you as Kapitan, myself as First Comrade; even Zamora and Kanzaki.
I thought Zamora was a criminal and Kanzaki was a snitch.
Not all duties are created equal. We are strong when we purge ourselves of opportunists. And the fact remains that the duty of a hundred may be undone by the dereliction of one.
You're in the INPF first and the Red Navy second, you know.
My country strove for the liberation of all people from their chains before the world was threatened. It will do so after. State and class will wither away and war itself will pass into history.
Consider the war with the Morganas a prelude to the greater human struggle. What will be left after we warships wither away?
Where does that leave Zamora?
Exactly where I put him, until he sees things as I do.
*ALARM*
Not in the line of fire, hopefully.
Think very hard before you reject a tactic outright.
@BATTLE
Come to stargaze, Captain?
Is that what you've been doing out here?
... After a fashion.

Fields.MenuText: For a materialist, you can be remarkably nebulous.
Do you have a favorite constellation?
Whatever it is, I hope you don't mind company.

Fields.DialogueText: The irony is not lost on me. It simply... is.
There are many that are beautiful, but I prefer a sunrise most of all.
I wish you could share in it, Kapitan. Truly.
You know what's funny?
Speak.
The other day, when you asked me what the first thing I'd heard about you was... I wasn't being entirely honest.
Weren't you?
It's silly.
Try me.
Back when I was officially assigned to you... the rumor was that your smokestacks spat out the Northern Lights instead of smoke.
... Heh.
Which, in fairness, made sense to me at the time. You Belles have a certain magic about you, and Aurora...
My namesake is not aurora borealis, though I forgive you the assumption. It is not an uncommon sight at my latitudes.
No, Kapitan, I am named for the Roman dawn goddess.
That doesn't bother you?
A name taken from an ancient religion that was bent to the curiosity of those who ruled by another god's will? I suppose Diana and Pallada might have chafed at theirs.
But they are not here. The tsars are not here. The Romans are long gone, and the Third Rome with them. I remain, and I have a greater purpose than any of them could have dreamed of.
Somehow it seems... I don't know.
Out with it.
When you talk about your purpose... well, it just seems like you've got one foot... somewhere else. Earlier, when you--
Ukryt'sya!
*BOOM*
That was too close. I felt that one.
You are not entirely wrong, Kapitan. We will leave it at that for now.
@BATTLE
He has a gentle reminder from the military censor about sowing discord around the war effort. He has firm recommendations otherwise from you and I.
He'd do it again, you know.
Any paradigm of morality must allow for reform. This can be done through hard work and sacrifice.
Keep to your business and I'll keep to mine.
We both know how to do our jobs.

Fields.MenuText: The more things change...

Fields.DialogueText: Rich historical experience has taught me that few things truly do.

Fields.MenuText: It's too quiet. I almost miss their arguments.
I'd prefer not to have to break them up again.

Fields.DialogueText: Life has become more joyous indeed.
If I have read them correctly, that is no concern of ours.
He has half rations for the rest of the tour.
Would he?
Si.
Hai.
He's a true believer. God is on Franco's side, Stalin's on... well, the other side.
You wish to second-guess my decision?
All I'm saying is that you can't force everyone to believe as you do.
And not to court a sedition trial or anything, but I'm still not sure about turning an unfortunate casualty into a martyr.
You will learn my virtues or you will be buried by them.
Yeah, I got that far.
You are not one to be buried, Kapitan, even if you have much yet to learn.
I love you too.
Heh. I suppose that would help. Shall we?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Aurora?
*BOOM*
@BATTLE
I never said the Funayūrei killed my father. Zhukov's barbarians butchered him at Nomonhan.
You filled in the blank yourself. I learned long ago to let your enemy tell the lie for you.
... So then we pass by Gotland. There are some Gnevnys in the area I'm sure will be pleased to see you, Aurora.
Da, Kapitan. Excuse me. I was... elsewhere.
Well, it's all right. I don't suppose--
Gah!
What the hell was that!? Aurora, on your feet! Are you all right?
I'm... I'll be all right, Kapitan. But you may need to fight this one without me. My boiler--
What do you mean, "this one?" We're nowhere near--
*ALARM*
Oh, hell.
I will personally see to the repairs. Deal with this! They are no great threat to us!
Here he is, Kapitan. He's hurt, but he's conscious.
Leave us.
Yes, Comrade Aurora.
At least you made it, Kanchou. I knew I didn't have a future in engineering.
Explain yourself.
I put away my pride. I came to the other side of the world to get ahead of the real enemy.
We're out here fighting the real enemy every day! And after the Morganas killed your father... it doesn't make sense. Bombing your own ship...
And thank goodness Aurora believes in reform through work.
I still do, Comrade Kanzaki. I've a secure job in mind for you. At a workman's wage, no less.
Send me wherever you like. I'm not the only one who sees where this war is going. Once there are no more Funayūrei to keep you bastards busy--
I've heard enough. Take him to the brig.
Other than that, we'll have to double the watches. The central Baltic is still teeming with...
Then you shouldn't mind a letter or two from the Imperial Japanese Navy.
I'll say. I'm sure they'll have some more vetting to... wait.
Ugh. I hope this isn't a sign of things to come.
Let's see... Pravda, magazine, magazine, Command... ah, two from Command. One for you, one for me.
Spasibo, Kapitan. I've been looking forward to this one.
And here I thought you appreciated international cooperation.
I'm not talking about the lend-lease. I've got the Royal Navy and the Spanish Navy baying in my ear about the recent casualties.
The strangely bright side to all this is that with the Red Fleet stage-managing my correspondence, I really don't have to shoulder this end of the conversation.
A shame about Zamora, and I do mean that.

Fields.MenuText: I'll say. A boiler rupture... what a horrible way to go.
I'm sure he would have appreciated hearing you say that.
He and Kanzaki had their differences, but I never guessed one would kill the other.

Fields.DialogueText: I mildly doubt it. He believed in a grand design, but not in mine.
A great many killers are acquaintances of their victims. Just ask Bukharin.
You don't know how right you are.
Kapitan?
Aurora, is Kanzaki still in his quarters?
Waste a perfectly good set of eyes? Kapitan, why would I cut off my nose to spite my face?
No, Kapitan, he can think on his sins on watch as well as anywhere else.
Aurora, we're in one of the most Morgana-infested seas in Europe! If you drift off again--
That's just it, Kapitan.
*BOOM*
I've never been more awake.
@BATTLE
South toward the Polish coast, if I recall correctly.
You killed him. My own Belle, a member of her crew...
There was once a great revolution in my country. It was hamstrung by opportunists and cowards who hid in the Winter Palace while the world left them behind.

Fields.MenuText: I don't have much of a choice, do I?
You'll have to kill me.

Fields.DialogueText: ... You drive a hard bargain, Kapitan.
Where do we go from here, Aurora?
I calculated a risk and took it. He was prepared to accept any price for opposing me. This was one.
Few sailors have what it takes to crew a Belle. But you chose me, and you're stuck with me.
You are a constant, Kapitan, and I intend to keep you that way... by any means necessary.
Healthy distrust makes a good base for cooperation.
And Zamora? Was he part of the plan too?
The only difference between him and Kanzaki was ambition. Doubt is poison. It must be burned out lest it fester into resentment and rebellion.
Besides, would I have let Kanzaki act if I'd had any doubt that he would fail?
How many of us are you willing to spend to win this war?
October came. I signaled the attack. I burned them out. And this time, we got it right. We have no such second chance with the Morganas. I've seen it.
You've still got your moments to answer for, you realize. I could be following a senile ship spirit into battle for all I know.
All in good time, Kapitan. You'll learn these things as they become important to you.
You are one kapitan. I am one Belle. The Morganas will fall upon a divided humanity and feast, or they will find a world united in purpose. You will help us to build that world.
I'll go along, but I'm still your captain and I still command you. I know for a fact I'm not a variable you'd like to alter in waters like these.
Crew on watch accept the possibility of being the first Morgana casualty. He knew this when I assigned him.
Don't give me that. I'm talking about Kanzaki.
And you knew the Morganas' angle of approach.
